Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Swagger \Swag"ger\, n. The act or manner of a swaggerer. [1913 Webster]
He gave a half swagger, half leer, as he stepped forth to receive us. --W. Irving. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44
The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Swagman \Swag"man\, n. A bushman carrying a swag and traveling on foot; -- called also {swagsman}, {swagger}, and {swaggie}. [Webster 1913 Suppl.]
Once a jolly swagman sat beside a billabong Under the shade of a coolibah tree. And he sang as he sat and watched his billy boiling, `Who'll come a-waltzing Matilda with me?' --[Waltzing Matilda, an Australian tune.] [PJC]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Swagger \Swag"ger\, v. i. [imp. & p. p. {Swaggered}; p. pr. & vb. n. {Swaggering}.] [Freq. of swag.] 1. To walk with a swaying motion; hence, to walk and act in a pompous, consequential manner. [1913 Webster]
A man who swaggers about London clubs. --Beaconsfield. [1913 Webster]
2. To boast or brag noisily; to be ostentatiously proud or vainglorious; to bluster; to bully. [1913 Webster]
What a pleasant it is . . . to swagger at the bar! --Arbuthnot. [1913 Webster]
To be great is not . . . to swagger at our footmen. --Colier. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Swagger \Swag"ger\, v. t. To bully. [R.] --Swift. [1913 Webster]

swagger adj : (British informal) very chic; "groovy clothes" [syn: {groovy}] n 1: an itinerant Australian laborer who carries his personal belongings in a bundle as he travels around in search of work [syn: {swagman}, {swaggie}] 2: a proud stiff pompous gait [syn: {strut}, {prance}] v 1: to walk with a lofty proud gait, often in an attempt to impress others; "He struts around like a rooster in a hen house" [syn: {ruffle}, {prance}, {strut}, {sashay}, {cock}] 2: discourage or frighten with threats or a domineering manner; intimidate [syn: {browbeat}, {bully}] 3: act in an arrogant, overly self-assured, or conceited manner [syn: {bluster}, {swash}]
